content.title: Venous Thoracic Outlet Syndrome (Paget-Schroetter Syndrome)
content.definition: Acute thrombosis of the axillary-subclavian vein due to repetitive compression at the thoracic outlet, typically occurring in young, active individuals after vigorous upper extremity activity. Also known as 'effort thrombosis' or Paget-Schroetter syndrome.

key_concepts.description: Repetitive compression of subclavian vein between first rib and clavicle/subclavius muscle during arm elevation → endothelial damage → thrombosis. Often precipitated by vigorous exercise
Young, healthy, athletic individuals (20-40 years); male predominance; dominant arm affected; athletes (swimmers, baseball pitchers, weight lifters), manual laborers
Sudden arm swelling, pain, cyanosis following activity; heavy sensation; visible superficial venous collaterals on shoulder and chest; may have history of prior transient symptoms
Chronic form with intermittent venous obstruction and prominent collaterals; may not have complete thrombosis; precursor to Paget-Schroetter
Duplex ultrasound shows non-compressible subclavian/axillary vein; venography defines extent and anatomy; MRV/CTV for thoracic outlet evaluation
Symptoms and imaging abnormalities may be more pronounced with arm abduction and external rotation (throwing position); dynamic venography useful
Urgent thrombolysis (catheter-directed) followed by anticoagulation; then first rib resection to decompress thoracic outlet; venoplasty for residual stenosis
First rib resection ideally performed 2-4 weeks after thrombolysis (inflammation subsided); earlier surgery if refractory symptoms; delays >3 months associated with poorer outcomes
Transaxillary or supraclavicular approach to remove first rib and anterior scalene muscle; decompresses costoclavicular space; standard treatment after thrombolysis
High recurrence rate (up to 60%) if only anticoagulated without rib resection; athletes may not return to sport without decompression

learning_objectives: Recognize the classic presentation (young athlete, arm swelling after activity)
Understand the treatment algorithm (thrombolysis → rib resection)
Know that anticoagulation alone has high recurrence rate
clinical_pearls: Young athlete + sudden arm swelling after activity = Paget-Schroetter
Thrombolysis first → then first rib resection (2-4 weeks later)
Collateral veins on chest/shoulder = chronic component
Need to decompress thoracic outlet or will rethrombus
common_mistakes: Delaying first rib resection beyond 3 months
Missing the diagnosis in young patients (not 'typical DVT age')
Not doing venography in provocative position
